captions.text:
How to Care for a Pet Guinea Pig. Guinea pigs
often squeak with joy when their owners enter

a room. How can you resist such welcoming
pets? You will need A companion guinea pig

or two A guinea pig pen that's at least 4
sq. ft. in size Newspaper &amp; bedding, such

as aspen shavings, shredded paper, or pellet-type
Guinea pig food, such as hay, pellets, greens,

and vegetables A one-qt. animal water bottle
Hiding places, such as empty coffee cans,

shoeboxes, and flowerpots A small pet brush
A hard-sided wading pool and guinea pig vitamin

c tablets. Step 1. Before you actually bring
your guinea pig home, do a little research

online and in magazines and books. Guinea
pigs need more care and attention than you

might expect. Step 2. Guinea pigs are social
animals—they’d much rather live with another

guinea pig or two than by themselves. If you
want your little squeaker to be the happiest,

get her a friend. Step 3. Female guinea pigs
can usually live comfortably together. Male

guinea pigs should be from the same litter
to reduce grumpiness and fighting. And since

guinea pig neutering isn’t widely available,
don’t keep males and females in the same

pen. Step 4. Guinea pigs need plenty of space
to run around. One guinea pig needs at least

four square feet of space—but the roomier,
the better. Step 5. Guinea pigs’ feet are

delicate. Don’t keep them in wire-bottomed
cages. Instead, use cages with solid bottoms,

and line the cage or pen with newspaper topped
with plenty of hay, shredded paper, or recycled

pellet-type bedding. A hard-sided children’s
wading pool makes a good guinea pig pen. Step

6. A guinea pig’s main food source should
be fresh, high-quality timothy hay. Feed your

piggies as much hay as they’ll eat—they
need the fiber, and munching on hay is the

best way to keep their teeth from growing
too long. Step 7. Guinea pigs depend on their

owners to provide them with vitamin C. Commercial
guinea pig pellets contain the necessary amount

of C. Generally, one adult guinea pig needs
a ¼ cup of pellets per day. Use fresh pellets,

as vitamin C breaks down, and don’t substitute
rabbit pellets, which aren’t the same thing.

Many guinea pigs think Vitamin C tablets are
a treat. Give your piggies a quarter of a

tablet once a week, or sprinkle a crushed
tablet over their food. Step 8. Guinea pigs

should also have a handful of varied greens
and vegetables each day. Provide those high

in vitamin C like kale, dandelion greens,
and strips of red pepper. Step 9. Guinea pigs

drink tons of water. Make sure yours have
clean, fresh water available at all times.

Step 10. Guinea pigs love having hiding places
to play and sleep in. Try empty coffee cans,

shoeboxes with holes cut in them, and overturned
flowerpots. While guinea pigs like to play,

they’re not particularly nimble—offer
them balls and low ramps for exercise. Step

11. Give your guinea pigs plenty of “floor
time” each day. Let them run around in a

space that’s free of wires and other dangers—you
don’t want them nibbling on your computer

cords! Step 12. Many guinea pigs love to be
brushed. Longhaired guinea pigs should be

brushed every day. Step 13. Call a small-animal
veterinarian if your guinea pigs are sneezing

or coughing, have diarrhea, or seem lethargic.
A happy, healthy guinea pig can live for up

to 10 years, so with good care your little
friend will be around for a nice long time.

Did you know Excited guinea pigs sometimes
jump up and down—a behavior called “popcorning.”

title: How to Care for a Pet Guinea Pig

comments.text:
Hi ObiJuanKenobi3, here is a step by step about how to clean its cage..


1st. Start by removing your guinea pigs from the cage. When you are 
cleaning the cage out it is best to have the guinea pig in a safe place, 
preferably where you can see them.


2nd. Remove any toys, food or water bowls. If your guinea pigs have a water 
bottle it should be fine to leave it on the door while the hutch cleaning 
is in progress.


3rd. Remove all the bedding from the cage, trying not to spill any. If you 
have newspaper underneath the bedding you can simply roll it up, trapping 
the bedding inside, and remove it. If you don't have newspaper you will 
probably need to use a brush to sweep it all out.
 

4th. Use  vinegar and water solution to scrub down the cage bottom.


5th. Line the cage with your bedding of choice (recycled paper bedding such 
as Critter Care, Aspen wood shavings, or moisture winking fleece over 
towels). Never use cedar, saw dust, pine that isn't kiln dried, or straight 
paper/newspaper as bedding because all contribute to upper respiratory 
problems in guinea pigs.
 


6th. Add a high quality grass hay such as timothy hay, orchard grass hay, 
or bluegrass hay to the hay holders. Avoid using straw as this can have 
quite sharp ends and could hurt the guinea pigs as they have fairly 
sensitive skin compared to other animals.
 

7th Place the food bowls, water bottles and toys back in the cage.


8th. Finally you can put the guinea pigs back in their cage and watch them 
explore their fresh, clean home.

comments.author: RMS Titanic 1912-2015

comments.text: Kidwithcamera: the guinea pig is an Abyssinian guinea pig﻿
comments.author: KayKay Fredrick

comments.text:
Not sure when this video was made, but balls and wheels are not safe for 
guinea pigs. They cause back problems and should be avoided. Also be 
careful when putting two males together, even if they are from the same 
litter. Even with the recommended space for two pigs (10sq ft) there is a 
high possibility that the males will fight. Have a back up cage in case 
this happens. A single guinea pig should have at least 8 sq ft of living 
space. It is important to do research prior to even going near the animal. 
Guinea pigs are small but can be a lot of work and require a lot of 
attention. I like to say: "if it's not hard work, you're not doing it 
right. "﻿
comments.author: KayKay Fredrick

comments.text:
Hi, I just started a channel called gpcareguide (Guinea Pig Care Guide.) 
Videos on my channel will include, how to clean a guinea pig cage, how to 
bathe a guinea pig, and much more. Feel free to subscribe and make video 
requests!!!﻿
comments.author: Guinea Pig Care Guide

comments.text:
Make sure you don't give your Guinea pig potatoes or regular lettuce....Do 
some research before you get a Guinea Pig....They might not cost a fortune 
to buy one, but they cost a lot of money to take care of one. Please make 
sure the person you are getting your pig from can show you how to tell the 
difference between a male and a female. The last thing this world needs is 
unwanted animals of any sort.﻿

comments.author: Molly2471

comments.text:
I've been raising guineas since I was 5. (50 years now) The only thing I 
don't recommend is the unsecured pool as a pen. It's good for a playpen if 
used when the piggy is supervised. The film also didn't mention how 
important it is to schnuggle and pay individual attention to each piggy 
every day. Love and hug your piggies, its as necessary as food.﻿
comments.author: Debbie Bishop
